INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate of the presence of His Excellency Dr Francesco Cossiga, President of the Italian Republic. On behalf of the Senate I extend to His Excellency a warm welcome to Australia and to the Senate. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite Dr Cossiga to take a seat on the floor of the chamber.

INTERJECT.PARA: Dr Cossiga thereupon entered the chamber, and was seated accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate extends a warm welcome to Australia and to the Senate to His Excellency Dr Francesco Cossiga, President of the Italian Republic, and expresses the hope that his visit will be an enjoyable and fruitful one and will confirm the cordial relations between our two countries.

Australia's links with Italy may be traced back a century or more to the period before the unification of Italy. Perhaps not many Australians know this but it is a fact that there was an Italian, one Raffaelo Carboni, at the Eureka Stockade. Perhaps the words `avanti popolo' which later became famous in Italy were first heard at the Eureka Stockade in Ballarat. Italian participation in Australia's migration programs in the 1950s and subsequently is a foundation on which the present much broader links have been built and which ensures the significant personal awareness of each country in the other. Over 300,000 of today's Australians were born in Italy and another half a million or so are of Italian extraction. These Australians have made an enormous contribution to Australia's economic prosperity and to the enrichment of our cultural life. They are highly valued and respected members of the Australian community.

We thank President Cossiga for his visit during our bicentennial year. Italy has played a very prominent part in those celebrations. Many senators have probably visited the Italian pavilion at World Expo 1988 in Brisbane. Bologna hosted a very interesting and well attended conference on Australia earlier this year and there was an Australian pavilion at the Venice Biennale in June. In May this permanent Parliament House was officially opened. The architect is an Italian and so is some of the marble and craftsmanship. The Italian Navy participated in the recent naval review in Sydney Harbour. The artistic highlight of Italy's contribution to our Bicentennial is Italy on Stage, a magnificent festival with 500 artists presenting music, theatre and ballet around Australia, some of which will be performed in the presence of His Excellency President Cossiga. Our business ties with Italy are significant and I think they will become even more so. Many of our larger construction firms were established by Italian migrants. Australia and Italy are substantial trading partners. Our total trade in 1987 was over $A2 billion. I believe that we can do even better than that.

Yesterday, Mr President, I had lunch with the Foreign Minister of Italy, Mr Andreotti. He told me that the Italian Parliament is about to consider a change to its standing orders which would require open voting instead of the present system which provides for a secret vote in parliament. I suspect that some members of the Opposition in this Parliament sometimes wish that we practised the Italian system. But on this occasion, in moving that the Senate welcome you, President Cossiga, and your party, I am certain that all honourable senators will be enthusiastic in publicly recording their support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Opposition warmly supports this motion. I wish to invite Senator John Panizza to support it on behalf of the Opposition. I do so in part not because I am speechless with pleasure at the President's visit; I am simply speechless. Senator Panizza is, of course, an Australian whose parents came from Italy and we would like him to speak on our behalf on this important occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to support the motion on behalf of the Opposition. We join in welcoming you, Dr Cossiga, to Australia and express the hope that your visit will be enjoyable.

SPEECH.PARA: Your Excellency, you are visiting a country to which Italians have made a great contribution. As you probably know, Italians first migrated to Australia in numbers around the 1860s. They went into different areas-mostly the harsher areas. They worked in mines. They were engaged in timber felling, cutting sugar, clearing land and the like. They worked in these areas mainly until World War II. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has said, after World War II the Italian migrants who were here and those who came to this country moved into the professions, businesses and primary industries where they farmed wheat and wool, grew beef and sugar cane and engaged in dairying. All of those industries benefited from their endeavours. As I have said, mining certainly progressed because of the amount of work that they did. Eventually, Italians got into the building industry and highway and bridge construction. They also entered the fashion industry. Carla Zampatti, probably the most well-known fashion name in Australia, is from northern Italy. Italians have also entered the retail and hospitality trades. Many members of this chamber certainly make good use of the hospitality provided by Italian restaurants. Australians have gained many skills that have been brought to this country by Italians.

My family originated from the province of Sondrio in north Italy. I can speak with first-hand knowledge of the opportunity that Australia has provided. It is one thing for migrants to come to this country but it is another thing for the host country to provide opportunities. I feel that my family and many others are living proof of what can be achieved in Australia as a result of the opportunities which Australia provided.

Older Italians worked hard and deprived themselves of a lot of things so that their children could have what they did not have. One of those was education. As you probably know, Mr President, education was not for everyone in Italy in the early 1920s. Because of the instability of some governments of the time, Italians went all over the world-not only to Australia but also to America, Canada, South Africa and the like-looking for opportunities. As I said, they got those opportunities in Australia. As a result, younger Italians have been able to go into the professions. They have certainly achieved good results there.

Italian names appear among university professors, in the professions of medicine, law, dental science, politics and, probably the most important of all, engineering. We have Italian judges and Italian mayors. In fact, Mayor Cattalini, the mayor of Fremantle, the city which hosted the America's Cup, was my guest here last night. I understand that there are now nine Italian members of parliament around Australia. I believe that the President of the Legislative Council of Victoria is an Italian. I also believe that Victoria has an Italian judge. Incidentally, Mr President, you will be happy to know that the first Italian born member of the House of Representatives, Mr Sciacca, was elected to that House last year.

In sport also Italian names have come to the fore-famous names such as Barrassi, Silvagni, Pianto, Marchesi, people in Victoria who have made Australian Rules famous. My family name has not done too badly in South Australia, and certainly in Western Australia there are a lot of Italian names in sport. Also, there is an Italian who, if he has not yet made test cricket, is about to do so; that is, young Mike Valetta in Western Australia.

In total, Italian migrants have achieved a great deal for Australian society: not only have they contributed to our economy and culture but they have also contributed to Australian family life. Italian family life is certainly respected in Australia. Speaking as an Australian now, Mr President, I can assure you that many Australian families envy the Italian type of family life. Italians have proved that they are the types of migrants that can fully integrate into Australian society, as they have integrated into societies in all parts of the world. On behalf of the Opposition, I welcome the opportunity to take into Australia many more migrants in the near future.

Mr President, I wish you very well for the rest of your trip in Australia. I hope it will be most enjoyable, and I certainly look forward to my next visit to your country. That is something I do as often as I can and will do again as soon as I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me particular pleasure today to join in welcoming Dr Cossiga to Australia and to the Senate chamber. Much has been said already about the contribution made by Italy and Italians to Australia. This was said at lunch; it was said a few moments ago by Senators Button and Panizza. And those contributions, of course, have included the cultural and economic contribution made by Italian migrants as well, of course, as the more recent very generous contribution made by the Italian people and Government to Australia's bicentennial celebrations.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said a moment ago, it gives me particular pleasure to speak here today, because only a matter of some two or three weeks ago, as a member of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the European Parliament, I had the privilege of actually meeting Dr Cossiga in his own country and indeed in his own office. It is quite a different experience to meet the President of the Republic of Italy in the sorts of circumstances in which one does over there, surrounded by the ancient and unique beauty of the Italian culture in its own setting. Dr Cossiga was particularly generous in allowing the delegation access to some of the several hundred rooms of the palace in which he has his office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am joined in that expression of thanks by one of my colleagues on the delegation, Senator Michael Baume. In fact, I do not think it is going too far to say that we almost overdosed on cathedrals, ceilings, marble and artistry as we moved around Italy, and the President's palace is a classic example of everything that is beautiful and needs to be preserved in Italy.

SPEECH.PARA: The President also gave us a tremendous amount of his time and discussed a wide range of topics with the members of the delegation, and we could not help being struck by the impressive knowledge that the President had and by the views that he was able to pass on to us. The President's background, as I dare say many honourable senators know, is in constitutional law, and his detailed knowledge of the Australian and Canadian constitutions was immediately apparent. Indeed, it was a quite striking contrast to the appalling lack of knowledge of the Australian Constitution that I think many Australians have. We were somewhat awed by his erudition in this area.

We were also able to be part of some discussions with the President and his colleagues about the difficulties of constitutional reform, apt in the wake of our own referendum proposals here. The Senate might be interested to know that while we were there the Italian Senate was debating a number of constitutional changes including an end to the secret ballot provisions that operate in the Italian Parliament. Some changes were being suggested with regard to impeachments of Ministers-Ministers who have been charged with some sort of criminal offence.

What was also important to Australia-and I think to the President and other members of Parliament that we spoke to while we were there-was the problems affecting Europe and Australia as 1992 approaches. We benefited considerably from the President's own comments with regard to the coming harmonisation in Europe. I think Senator Baume will acknowledge that we shared his cynicism with regard to possible economic benefits since, as he pointed out, he has not run into an economist yet who has been able to explain clearly what the benefits, ramifications and outcomes are likely to be in 1992. Certainly, Australia needs to look to expand such areas as joint ventures based in Italy and other European countries as well as joint ventures based in Australia if we want to hedge our bets in that area. Along with my Australian Democrat colleagues I welcome the President of the Republic of Italy and hope that he derives as much pleasure and benefit from his visit to Australia as we did on the parliamentary delegation to his country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Vessels in Australian Waters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and senators in Parliament assembled: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, strongly urge that the Australian Government prohibit the entry of nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered vessels into Australian ports or waters during our bicentennial celebrations and at any other time in the future.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: In-vitro Fertilisation Patients: Medicare Funding
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows a request for Medicare benefits for in-vitro fertilisation for the medical treatment of infertile couples.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled grant Medicare benefits for in-vitro fertilisation, IVF, for the medical treatment of infertile couples. 1 in 10 Australian couples are infertile and unable to conceive and carry a baby to birth. Having a family is one of the most fundamental and rewarding aspects of life and benefits the community as a whole. IVF is an established and proven treatment for infertility. There are existing mechanisms to regulate and control IVF, including the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee. Currently IVF patients pay up to $1500 per treatment cycle for IVF out of their own pockets. This means that some couples who need IVF to help them establish their own family do not have access. We request that Medicare funding be granted for IVF for the treatment of infertility.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park; and

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And you petitioners, as in duty bound will ever hope.

PETITION.TITLE: Report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: We the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Reynolds (from 61 citizens) and Watson (from 254 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Post Office, Invermay, Launceston
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That any decision by Australia Post to close the Invermay Post Office in Launceston will severely inconvenience many aged and infirm residents of the area and further decrease the postal and other services provided to the public.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate should ensure that Australia Post maintains a postal service in the suburb of Invermay.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: War and Violence Related Toys, Games and Video Games
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that
(1) they are gravely concerned over the availability of war toys and other combat or violence related toys and games, including video games, in our country;
(2) they believe there is sufficient scientific evidence to show that these kind of toys and games are educationally unsound, psychologically damaging to children, and socially undesirable.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: that the Senate will take measures to end all trading in war and violence related toys, games and video games, through either self-regulation by the traders in these products, or legislative action.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask: What is the Government's current position on taxes and wages? Is it a tax cut and a wage increase, as promised by the Prime Minister? Is it a tax cut but no wage increase, as suggested by the Treasurer? Is it neither, as threatened by Senator Walsh?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is playing with words and, indeed, with the truth to say that Senator Walsh threatened anything. Let me say that, of course, it has been said since the time of the Budget that the Government would be approaching the wages issue in the early part of 1989 on the basis of a tax-wage trade-off. At the time of the Budget it was said that the size of the tax cut would depend, amongst other things, on the movement in wages that took place following the national wage case of this year and prior to March 1989. The question of a balance between tax cuts and wage rises is something that must be determined, having regard to a number of matters which are likely to take place before that issue is negotiated. It is a matter of taking those factors into account and arriving at an appropriate balance.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has said on at least one occasion that the most desirable thing would be for the tax cuts to be of sufficient amounts to negate the necessity for a wage rise, in the light of the Government's statement that it will preserve the level of real wages throughout next year. But again that is a matter which remains to be seen, and it is a matter of judgment at the time as to what will be the appropriate course. The Government will advise when it has reached a conclusion about that matter next year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. So that the Minister cannot accuse me of not quoting Senator Walsh correctly, I shall quote from his speech made on Friday, 7 October 1988, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: For simplicity, I will assume an `average earner' to be a person with a taxable income of $24,000.
Such a person presently pays $5,601 tax. A tax cut of $56 a week would reduce that liability by $2,912 or 52 per cent.

I ask the Minister: Does he agree with Senator Walsh's statement that an average worker would need a reduction in his or her tax liability of 52 per cent to make up for the imposts of the Hawke Government imposed between March 1983 and 1 July 1989?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understood the burden of Senator Walsh's comments on the $56 reduction in tax, it was to illustrate the utter innumeracy of the Opposition and its incapacity, as always, to make any sensible calculations that will lead to a sensible economic result. That is what Senator Walsh was concerned to do. I do not believe this is a supplementary question at all, Mr President, because in Senator Lewis's first question he asked whether I agreed with the threat made by Senator Walsh. The only threat in Senator Walsh's comments, as quoted by Senator Lewis, was aimed at the credibility of the Opposition, but that is not much of a threat. The credibility of the Opposition in terms of numeracy is rock-bottom, and there was no threat in what Senator Walsh said.

—I ask the Minister for Finance a question about the average living standards in the Australian community. The Minister has stated that real household disposable income per capita increased by 4.4 per cent between 1982-83 and 1987-88. I was concerned to hear a subsequent claim that that was largely due to a rise in capital-sourced income received by the very wealthy in the community. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether that claim is true?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The simple answer is that the claim is not true, but I will not just leave that hanging in the air-I will produce the evidence. I have seen Mr Peacock's press release and he clearly has difficulties with the concept of an average. The figure for average weekly earnings which he likes to use is an average of the wages and salaries of all adult full time wage and salary earners. That means that it includes the salary of the Federal President of the Liberal Party, for example, as well as the wages of less well paid Australian workers. The average that Mr Peacock likes to use appears to be an average of adult male full time wage and salary earners, which therefore obviously ignores the one million self-employed, the 1 1/2 million retired people, be they social security recipients or not, and the fact that almost three million women are in the paid work force. Surely the average living standard of the Australian community is what applies to all Australians and not just to a subsection of them. But I have asked my Department to check on Mr Peacock's claim. I will quote Mr Peacock:

ANSWER.PARA: the increases in Senator Walsh's aggregate measure of real per capita household disposal income have been largely due to a rise in capital sourced incomes . . .

When I asked members of my Department to analyse and check this claim, they informed me that if real household disposable income per capita were recomputed with income received by households from interest, dividends and rents excluded, the increase over the period-I repeat `the increase'-from 1982-83 to 1987-88 was 4 per cent as against 4.4 per cent if they were not excluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the 52 per cent you told us about?

—Senator Messner thinks that that is great news. Before he becomes too enthusiastic about it, let me tell him that when the figures are adjusted to exclude capital sourced incomes, although the growth figure between 1982-83 to 1987-88 goes down to 4 per cent real increase, the fall in real per capita disposable incomes in 1982-83-and who was in charge of the economy then, Senator Messner?-previously recorded at 1.8 per cent, declines to 2.5 per cent. So in the last year that the discredited former Treasurer had the principal responsibility for the management of the Australian economy, real per capita disposable incomes, with the rent, interest and dividends taken out of them, fell by 2 1/2 per cent in one year. In the last year that Mr Howard was in charge of this economy the incomes of ordinary Australians, with capital sourced income excluded, fell by 2 1/2 per cent; and on that basis they have increased by a net 4 per cent since.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer for Prices. Is the Minister aware of a recent Investigators report which describes some of the problems associated with door-to-door sales? The report in particular outlined complaints received by the South Australian Legal Services Commission about alleged malpractices by a South Australian frozen food sales company called Mr Freezer and specifically discussed the targeting of people with intellectual disabilities. Is the Minister aware of these complaints and what action is the Government planning to take to ensure that Mr Freezer adheres to responsible trade practices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crowley for raising this issue. It is one I am aware of and it appeared on the Investigators report, which detailed specific allegations received by the South Australian Legal Services Commission about the operation of Mr Freezer in South Australia.
—Put him on ice.

—I might be tempted to do so, Senator Aulich. There are two series of complaints about Mr Freezer, one related to a period in about February this year when complaints were made to both the South Australian Legal Services Commission and the South Australian Department of Consumer Affairs. Those complaints ranged on four specific levels: first, as to the cost of the services provided; secondly, the quality; thirdly, the approach and the manner of the salespersons involved operating for Mr Freezer, which from time to time were seen to be assertive, aggressive, tough, evasive and so on; and fourthly, misrepresentations on behalf of the organisation.

ANSWER.PARA: All of those complaints were brought together by the South Australian Department of Community Welfare and, together with the then Consumer Affairs Department's involvement and the Legal Services Commission, the matters were, I think, rectified in that all complaints, particularly all of those by pensioners, and disputes about the organisation were settled quite amicably. Because those complaints were settled the Federal Government, through the Trade Practices Commission, took a holding interest in the operation of the organisation. Commitments were made by Mr Freezer that the marketing strategy of that organisation would be changed and in fact that the practices that had been complained of would not be proceeded with. As a consequence, as from the middle of June this year, the Trade Practices Commission, as I said, conducted a holding operation of the Mr Freezer organisation.

However, since that date, particularly on 13 August, the Commission received a further complaint as well as three other complaints, totalling four, about the operation of the organisation. The complaints are very similar to the ones that were raised beforehand and are identical to those in the Investigators program. As a consequence of those complaints the Commission is waiting to take action. However, we are talking, firstly, through both State and Federal government agencies, to the Mr Freezer organisation to see whether we can, through the established processes, once again settle the problems involved. If that is not done, there is provision under the Trade Practices Act, particularly section 52a, to prosecute, amongst other things--

TALK.START.PARA: —Freeze his assets.

—To prosecute but not to freeze his assets. As I said, if the complaints are not settled amicably or to the satisfaction of the consumers involved, the Commission is at the ready to institute proceedings under section 52a of the Act to ensure that consumers in this instance and in the future are not ripped off in this way.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is the Minister aware that Dr John Colquhoun, the former Chairman of the Fluoridation Promotion Committee of New Zealand, has recently shown that there is equal or less tooth decay in unfluoridated Christchurch than in the other major cities of New Zealand, which are all fluoridated? He has also shown that the decline in tooth decay in New Zealand children commenced before the fluoridation of water supplies or the use of fluorides in any form. Is the Minister also aware that Dr Alan S. Gray, former Chief Dental Officer of British Columbia, Canada, has revealed that there is less tooth decay in the unfluoridated parts of his province than in the fluoridated parts? Is he aware that the incidence of tooth decay is the same in unfluoridated Brisbane as in fluoridated Adelaide and Perth? In short, is the Minister aware that there is growing scientific evidence that fluoridation of water supplies may be less effective than its proponents have claimed? If the Minister is aware of all this new evidence, will he initiate an open inquiry into fluoridation by people who are not committed to fluoridation and are independent of the usual dental advisers of the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Department of Community Services and Health?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that Dr John Colquhoun has been making claims concerning fluoridation in New Zealand and parts of Australia and that he is campaigning against fluoridation as a means of preventing dental decay. I am advised that data presented by Dr Colquhoun in Community Health Studies Volume II, pages 85 to 90, 1977, which purport to show that children in unfluoridated Christchurch, New Zealand, have less tooth decay than in fluoridated New Zealand cities, have a major discrepancy in that they fail to take into account the fluoride history of the children. The children in Christchurch would comprise a mixture of lifelong residents and newer arrivals. Similarly, the children in fluoridated cities would comprise lifelong residents and newer arrivals. The only valid way of comparing the effects of fluoridation on dental caries is to compare lifelong residents of a fluoridated community in the same geographic region. Dr Colquhoun has not done this.

ANSWER.PARA: The claim that dental decay declined before the introduction of fluoridation applies only to New Zealand five-year-olds. Extensive data is available for two older age groups, namely, eight- to nine-year-olds and 12- to 13-year-olds. This data shows that there was no decline in dental caries before the introduction of water fluoridation. I am advised that no data has appeared in the referred scientific literature from Dr A. S. Gray relating to dental decay in children in British Columbia, Canada, which takes into account a fluoride history of the subjects.

In relation to caries rates in Australian school children, the question apparently referred to data collected by school dental services of each State and processed by the Department of Community Services and Health. Such data cannot be used to draw inferences about the effectiveness of water fluoridation. It does not take into account such important factors as, first, the fluoride history of the subject; secondly, regional difference in dental caries; thirdly, the size and severity of caries lesions; and, fourthly, the number of primary teeth previously extracted because of dental caries.

The fluoridation of water supplies has been the subject of numerous inquiries in the past. There is no recent data which negates the support of the National Health and Medical Research Council for fluoridation of water supplies. A very comprehensive collection of reports and statements from all over the world entitled Fluoridation of Water was published in 1985 by the Department of Community Services and Health. The Department's view is that the evidence in support of continual fluoridation is overwhelming. I table for the interest of the honourable senator the document Fluoridation of Water-a collection of reports and statements from the Department of Community Services and Health.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the recent plebiscite in Chile, South America. What is the Australian Government's response to statements by the defeated General Pinochet that he will not allow free elections to be held as soon as possible, as now called for by the opposition parties? What is the Government's view of General Pinochet's stated intention not to allow early changes to the Chilean Constitution and to continue in office until 1990? Will the Australian Government be expressing its concern to the authorities in Chile about police brutality in repressing demonstrators in the aftermath of last week's plebiscite?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that, on 5 October, a clear majority-about 55 per cent-of Chileans rejected the prospect of a further eight years of rule by General Pinochet. The Australian Government welcomes the result of the plebiscite as a victory for democracy and the people of Chile. The 1980 Constitution provides that Chile will now proceed to open presidential and congressional elections late in 1989, with General Pinochet continuing as caretaker President until March 1990. There have been calls, mainly from some sections of the Opposition both in Chile and outside, for the election process to be accelerated. I am told that General Pinochet has reaffirmed his intention to adhere to the constitutional arrangements entered into in 1980.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government believes that the timing of open elections is a matter for the Chileans themselves to decide but, having regard to the history which I have just outlined, we would be hopeful that they would be as soon as possible within that framework. The Government also hopes that in the sensitive period ahead all sides will recognise the need for open and constructive dialogue in an atmosphere free of violence and rancour. We are aware of reports of violence arising from post-plebiscite demonstrations. It is vital that the liberalisation of public freedoms and political debate which preceded the plebiscite should be allowed to continue. The Australian Government will continue to urge respect for the human rights and democratic freedoms of all Chilean citizens wherever possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware that at a meeting of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) being held in Adelaide this week the hand-picked acting commissioners who were appointed following the recent sacking of the previous commissioners combined to pass a motion of no confidence in the Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission, Mrs Shirley McPherson? Is the Minister further aware that the same acting commissioners sought to secure the dismissal of the General Manager of the Commission, even though no questions have been raised as to the quality of his performance or the competence with which he has carried out his duties? Will the Minister ensure that the civil rights of the Chairman and General Manager are properly safeguarded-if necessary with a direction under section 11 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act? Most importantly, will the Minister for Justice, as the Minister appearing before Estimates Committee E with the officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission, ensure that all appropriate officers, in particular the Chairman and the current General Manager of the ADC, are made available for the Estimates Committee and ensure that there is no attempt to suppress information on this contentious issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the particular resolutions which Senator Boswell says were passed at a meeting of the Aboriginal Development Commission earlier this week-whether it was yesterday or today I am not quite sure. But I certainly will seek to confirm what resolutions have been passed which may be relevant to the chairperson of that Commission, Mrs Shirley McPherson, and the chief executive officer, Mr O'Brien. I will try to confirm that as soon as possible, maybe before the end of Question Time.

ANSWER.PARA: As to what was thought to be inferred from that particular course of action, if it were undertaken by the Aboriginal Development Commission or the Board, I would not wish in any way to accept any colouring of the action it may have undertaken in passing such motions, if indeed it did so. Until we get confirmation of that it is best that no assumption be made by honourable senators of the reasoning leading to those motions being passed. As to the Estimates Committee meeting, of course, as is the normal practice, those officers from both the Department and the Commission who are normally required in order to assist me in this particular instance in answering the legitimate questions of members of the Committee will be made available.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. On the subject of the Anzac frigates, I ask: If the New Zealand Government withdraws from the project for economic reasons, what consequences would there be for the Australian Government's relationship with New Zealand? Specifically, would there be retaliation from the Australian Government at an economic level or cuts in intelligence cooperation or cuts in defence cooperation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —New Zealand's participation in the Anzac ship program is for the New Zealand Government to decide on the basis of its own strategic and budgetary priorities. There is no question of Australia threatening New Zealand in relation to that decision. Australia and New Zealand have a close defence relationship which is very important to the strategic posture of both countries. The scope and vigour of our defence relationship naturally depends on the compatibility of our defence forces. In order to maintain a defence relationship with New Zealand, we believe it is important for New Zealand to continue to operate capable naval ships. We believe that for island nations like Australia and New Zealand blue water naval forces are essential. The New Zealand Government in its White Paper last year expressed the same conviction. The Anzac ship is being specifically developed by Australia and New Zealand to meet the needs of our region and will be built and maintained in Australia and New Zealand. It will provide both nations with the most cost-effective way of maintaining their maritime capabilities and sustain their close defence relationship.

—Mr President, my question, which is directed to you, relates to the motion of no confidence against Mrs Shirley McPherson passed within the last few days at a meeting of the Aboriginal Development Commission. In light of reports that one ground for censure of Mrs McPherson was her decision to present relevant evidence as an individual to a committee of the Senate pursuing a reference on behalf of the Senate, I ask you, Mr President, three questions: First, whether or not Mrs McPherson, or any other witness, has any protection from intimidation should they give evidence to a Senate committee; second, whether there has occurred any breach of privilege in this matter; and, third, whether you will set in motion the procedures relating to breaches of privilege should you receive from me or any other senator an appropriate letter on the matter.

—I had no knowledge of this question. I am not aware of the facts. Witnesses are, of course, protected. I will look into the other matters raised by Senator Baume and make a reply as soon as possible.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will you also look at the first part of my question-that is, what the extent of protection of witnesses is from intimidation should they appear before Senate committees?
—I will make a full statement on it.

—My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade relates to the death of Mr David Blenkinsop. Could the Minister advise the Senate what steps the Australian Government has taken to investigate claims that an Australian national, David Blenkinsop, was murdered by Indonesian police?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of inquiries have been conducted through the Australian Embassy in Jakarta. Information so far available makes it clear that an appalling tragedy has occurred. From the account given by David Blenkinsop's fiancee and other evidence, it appears the actions by the local Indonesian officials are, to say the least, reprehensible. I am sure that the Senate would concur in extending deep sympathy to the Blenkinsop family.

ANSWER.PARA: For a number of weeks our representatives in Jakarta have sought to obtain a satisfactory account of what occurred and have kept the family informed of developments. In the last few hours we have been advised by the Australian Embassy in Jakarta that the policeman involved in the incident has been suspended and will be charged under the military penal code, and that the civilian involved has been placed under arrest under the civilian penal code.

None of this, of course, will diminish the tragedy which has befallen the Blenkinsop family, but it puts the matter in a better light from the point of view of our bilateral relations with Indonesia. Our embassy in Jakarta will stay in the closest possible touch with the Indonesian authorities in order to obtain as much further information as possible and to endeavour to achieve a more satisfactory outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I draw the Minister's attention to his submission to the Parliamentary Remuneration Tribunal in which he stated that most members of the Australian Defence Force received a service allowance to compensate for restrictions on personal freedom, for working beyond normal hours and for disruption of family life. As the Minister clearly recognises the importance of the service allowance as compensation, as there is serious disaffection within the Services caused by the lack of equity in the service allowance, and in the light of the serious wastage of trained personnel from the Services, I ask the Minister: Why has the Government not recommended that a meaningful service allowance be extended to all ranks of the Australian Defence Force?

—I am sort of familiar with the question which Senator Newman asked, because I have had some correspondence about that issue from returned servicemen's organisations. Might I say that in getting that correspondence I must be regarded as somewhat unlucky. I was Acting Minister for Industrial Relations for a very short period, during which I happened to sign the submission to the Remuneration Tribunal. That does not matter; I am not complaining about that.
—It sounds to me like you are.

—A person of the honourable senator's churlish nature would turn anything into a complaint. Since I received correspondence about that matter I have written to the Minister for Industrial Relations and to the Minister responsible for repatriation to obtain further details about that issue and what the extent of--
—Try Defence.

—Well, I may have written to the Minister for Defence, too. I am grateful for the honourable senator's interjection. I have written to appropriate Ministers on the question of the policy in regard to defence allowances. As soon as I get an answer on that, I will be in a position to provide the honourable senator with one.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister noted the intemperate remarks made by the President of the Law Council of Australia, Mr Denis Byrne, criticising the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, in his endeavours to collect equitable tax from all eligible citizens? Is it not a fact that too many lawyers spend too much of their time advising companies and non-pay as you earn taxpayers how to evade or avoid their tax obligations, as distinct from PAYE taxpayers, who have no legally contrived schemes available to them to avoid or evade tax? Will the Minister give the Senate an assurance that the Australian Taxation Office and its Commissioner have the unequivocal support of the Government and the Parliament in their endeavours to have a tax system that operates in accordance with the principles of ability to pay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noticed-I think it was last week-the criticisms made by Mr Byrne. I was then asked whether it was a fact that too many lawyers spent too much of their time advising high income and usually non-PAYE taxpayers on how to evade or avoid tax. I do not know whether too many are currently doing that, but certainly in the past a very large number of lawyers devoted a lot of their time and such skills as they had to that end. Indeed, I do not know whether the Law Council per se was involved in this or whether it made public statements at the time of the late 1970s and early 1980s, but among the most shameful episodes, if not the most shameful, in the history of the Australian legal profession was the collaborative endeavours of tax evaders and prominent lawyers in that late 1970s-early 1980s period to pick the pockets of honest Australian taxpayers.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked by Senator Gietzelt whether I could give an assurance that the Taxation Office and the Commissioner of Taxation have the unequivocal support of the Government and the Parliament. I do not think I can answer about the Parliament because I do not know what the views of people in the Opposition are about this. But I can assure Senator Gietzelt that the Tax Commissioner has the unequivocal support of the Government, a fact which Mr Dawkins as Acting Treasurer has already made public. In expressing that view Mr Dawkins was expressing the view of the Treasurer, and indeed the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the announcement of discussions that would, if successful, extend Australia's arrangements with the China Steel Corporation beyond the present $250m a year by establishing a steel plant in Australia. Would the proposal fit in with the Government's steel plan and are there any fundamental obstacles that could prevent such a proposal proceeding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the report in the Australian Financial Review about this matter yesterday. At that time I had no information about it at all. I have asked for some inquiries to be made since I read that article. As I recall, it was a report from Taipei. Whether there has been any inquiry locally in Australia about the matter I am not sure at this stage. Senator Archer asked me whether it would fit in with the Government's steel plan. The Government's steel plan ends on 31 December 1988. It is quite unlikely that any major investment would be made before then. The question about whether it fits in with the plan will not be relevant. Whether it is desirable in terms of the Australian economy is a matter in respect of which one would want further information. My own view is that it would be and it would predominantly be a facility dedicated to exports. Of course, increased competition in the Australian marketplace may not be anything but a good thing.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of inhibitions regarding the matter, I think every foreign investment proposal has to receive foreign investment guideline approval. I do not think it is likely that there would be any objection to that but it has to go through the normal procedures which are much less onerous than they used to be. There may be other objections but none that I can see at present. If I can obtain further information about the matter I will make it available to Senator Archer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Does the decline in manufacturing production during the June quarter indicate poor prospects for the manufacturing sector in the future?
—It is a penetrating question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner interjects that it is a penetrating question. That is a very interesting interjection because it was Senator Chaney, his Leader, who alleged that it did have implications for manufacturing in the future; so that is the basis of the question. I regret that Senator Chaney is not here to hear the answer. Conclusions of this kind should not be based on the results of one quarter. It is true that manufacturing production did decline in the June quarter following five decades of very strong growth.
—Five quarters.

—Senator Walsh, who has a great skill and a penchant for precision as well as numeracy, as the Opposition well knows, has pointed out that I said `five decades' when I meant `five quarters'. If I said `five decades' that would have embraced the period when the Opposition was in government. It would have been a dreadful fib to say that production improved during that period.
—It would also embrace the Whitlam period.

—Certainly. I am perfectly ecumenical about that. It is five quarters. There are a number of factors influencing the decline in the June quarter, particularly the decline in food, beverages and tobacco resulting from the New South Wales floods. On the other hand, we have seen a resurgence of manufacturing under this Government. Production is now at record levels; 20 per cent higher than in 1983, more than 5 per cent higher than in 1987-88.
—How is employment going?
—Employment in manufacturing increased by some--
—Since you came to government?

—In Australia employment in manufacturing, if that is the purpose of Senator Hill's interjection, in the last two years has gone up significantly for the first time in 20 years. What is of regret is that Opposition commentators in talking about figures for one quarter seek to talk down what has been a significant recovery in the manufacturing sector. Senator Chaney said last week:

ANSWER.PARA: The downturn raises doubts about the competitiveness of the sector . . . for investment . . . and for exports.

In my view the outlook for manufacturing investment is very good. While investment fell in the June quarter, this also followed strong rises in previous quarters. Investment in 1987-88 was 6 per cent higher than in 1986-87. It is forecast to rise by 3 per cent in real terms in 1988-89.

The latest trade figures also provide little evidence for Senator Chaney's suppositions. Manufacturing exports were 16 per cent higher in the three months to August 1988 than in the same period in 1987. In August alone manufactured exports rose by 4 per cent.

Australia's international competitiveness, as measured by the unit labour cost index, for the June quarter 1988 shows that competitiveness is some 30 per cent better than in 1984 and almost 20 per cent higher again than in the early 1970s.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the recent strikes on Ansett Airlines of Australia which caused disruption to internal air flights. These were strikes over the number of flight attendants in the new Ansett Airbuses. I ask: Was there, or is there, as alleged by the strikers, some air safety issue involved? If so, what was the air safety issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought about this matter at great length as I sat at Melbourne Airport last Saturday for two or three hours. I did not come to a definitive conclusion. I have not investigated the matter myself but certainly now that Senator Hamer has raised the matter I will urgently refer it to Mr Willis to get a response to those air safety aspects to do with the dispute. Having done so, no doubt in two or three days when Senator Gareth Evans is back from overseas he will give Senator Hamer a considered response.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he has seen a press statement put out by the shadow Treasurer on Friday describing as patently absurd the Minister's statement:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . $56 appears to be based on the tax cut required so that an individual would be paying the same nominal amount of tax today as was the case in March 1983.
Can the Minister explain the derivation of this figure which Mr Howard claims to have originated, but which Mr Peacock has bandied about?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the press statement. The underlying facts behind my statement are these: in March 1983 the average total earnings of adult full time wage and salary earners was $344 per week-I will leave off the odd cents-on which the tax payable was nearly $77. In June 1988 the average total earnings, again for full time wage and salary earners, was $495 per week.

ANSWER.PARA: Assuming a 5.5 per cent wage growth by June of next year, that figure will become $523 per week, on which the tax payable will be $132. Again, I leave off the odd cents. However, by deducting the weekly tax of March 1983 from the weekly tax of June 1983-of course, these are in nominal dollars-the precise difference is $55.567, which of course rounds up to $56 a week. Perhaps Mr Peacock did not arrive at his $56 a week in that way. If he did not, I invite him to explain in which way he did arrive at it.

Whatever peculiar methodology Mr Peacock may have used-if, indeed, he used any methodology at all-it is a very peculiar view of `making up for the absence of tax scale indexation'. What Mr Peacock clearly fails to understand, regardless of what pseudo or voodoo methodology he may have used, is that if nominal income doubles over a period, and the nominal amount of tax remains the same, the average tax rate will halve, and the real level of tax revenue will be halved with it. Of course, Mr Peacock is the man who, a couple of months ago, told us he was not going to bring an accountant's view to these matters-an intention which, if I may say so, becomes more apparent every time he opens his mouth. I also note Mr Peacock's assertion in his press release that--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: the Minister has made an improper imputation about Mr Peacock in that last remark, and I ask him to withdraw.

—On the point of order, Mr President: Senator Walsh is quoting what I also heard Mr Peacock say, and he is entitled to do so. It is not unparliamentary. It may be ungracious, but it is certainly not unparliamentary.
—Order! I do not regard Senator Walsh's comments as being unparliamentary.

—For the record, I point out the desperation tactics that the Opposition has been employing for months. Every time the Opposition is getting a caning in Question Time, it raises spurious points of order.

ANSWER.PARA: I note the assertion in Mr Peacock's press release that `the Opposition has never advocated an average $56 a week tax cut'. I refer senators, firstly, to the Australian Financial Review of 29 August which states:
In an interview with The Australian Financial Review, the Shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock, was pleased to suggest personal tax cuts-around $56 a week for average earners . . .

If Mr Peacock has never advocated that, he should have corrected the Financial Review at the time. While he is about it, he might also care to correct one of the other less distinguished members of the Opposition front bench who, in a letter published in the Western Farmer on 22 September, said:
Australian families need tax relief now. A tax cut of $56 per week is necessary just to put the household income back to 1983 pre-Keating levels.

Of course, the latter assertion in that quotation is false. Mr Blunt is clearly advocating a tax cut of $56 a week, as I understand it, for average earners and presumably proportional reductions in taxation for people with incomes above and below average earnings. As I pointed out a couple of weeks ago, and repeated last week-although Senator Lewis chose not to quote that part of my speech today-the cost to revenue would be $23.5 billion. So we have two $20 billion men floating around as the leading economic spokesmen for the Opposition, advocating the irresponsible fiscal policy that the Opposition advocated about 15 months ago. Mr Peacock should really cease allowing Dr Hewson to set him up as a patsy in these matters in the way that he does.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Given the Government's decision to free up the public sector by making Commonwealth public authority commercial undertakings more responsive to market conditions by lessening Parliament's direct controls, including an authority's right to appoint private sector auditors, I ask the Minister: What are the so-called `enhanced measures of accountability' for the newly freed up authorities to be accountable to the Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to auditors, it is not in my view an easy question to decide whether government owned operators--
—What about auditors? What about accountability?

—I am coming to that. It is not easy to decide whether government owned business enterprises ought always to be audited by the Auditor-General or by some private auditor. I will cite one particular example which I find particularly difficult to deal with: the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, which itself is required to be audited by the Auditor-General, has a number of joint venture arrangements with the private sector. The condition of at least one of these joint venture arrangements was that the auditor chosen for the joint venture had to be mutually agreed between the two shareholders, which clearly gave the private sector shareholder the right to veto the appointment of the Auditor-General as the auditor if the private sector shareholder chose to do so. In fact, that is exactly what happened.

ANSWER.PARA: I can see no easy resolution to that problem, Senator Watson. As far as I am concerned, and I have been involved in this exercise for nearly four years, the bottom line of accountability to the Parliament is the return on the assets which are invested in public enterprises; that is, if the value of the assets is showing a proper return, after adjustment in some cases for acknowledged obligations to provide certain services which are by themselves uneconomic, that is the measure of control and the measure of accountability. But, of course, all business enterprises, be they in the public sector or the private sector, have to be accountable in the sense that their accounts must be presented accurately to their shareholders and to the public in general and they must not be involved in dishonest practices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister direct his answer to the thrust of the question about the enhanced measures of accountability to this Parliament?

—I have not got very much to add to what I said before. The final measure of accountability-and I have made this very plain throughout this exercise-is the economic performance of the enterprise. It is intended that there will be with all these enterprises a corporate plan which I expect to be made public. No, perhaps in all cases that may not be desirable, but it certainly will be made available to the Government. Unless there are good commercial in-confidence reasons for not doing so, I believe it should be published, and the performance of the enterprises can be measured against the projections in the corporate plan.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. In view of the longstanding concern in developing countries about the marketing practices relating to breast milk substitutes, what steps has the Australian Government taken to implement the World Health Organisation (WHO) code of marketing of breast milk substitutes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Article 11 of the World Health Organisation code, which is the one that Senator Giles refers to, does ask member governments to take action to give effect to the principles and aims of the code. The Australian Government has taken this to mean that the most appropriate action by way of implementation is not to legislate but to embark upon a number of alternative measures. At this stage I think only six countries in the world have, in fact, adopted the World Health Organisation code by way of legislation. Australia has decided, as have most other countries, to take the alternative course of action and has preferred to give effect to voluntary adoption of the principles of the code.

ANSWER.PARA: The code has been adopted by six countries, as I mentioned. Those six countries are the ones in which infant mortality is at the highest rates. As I said, our preferred approach has been to take the alternative and to promote voluntary adoption of the code. In doing so, we have taken three substantive measures. Firstly, we have negotiated with industry the adoption of the principles by way of an industry code of practice. This has been signed by manufacturers of infant formula. Secondly, and with reference to Article 9 of the WHO code, this aspect, which deals with product labelling, has been incorporated into Standard R7 of the food standards code, the standard which deals with infant formula. This code has been adopted in all Australian States, other than New South Wales and the Northern Territory. We anticipate that the New South Wales Government should, in an attempt to obtain uniformity with the rest of Australia, adopt the food standards code, and I gather the Australian Capital Territory has already indicated that it will adopt the code and in doing so will adopt this particular provision of it.

The third measure the Government has taken-an important one in terms of educating the community-is to publish a booklet in 17 languages entitled Baby's First Food. In essence, therefore, the Government's approach in the future, having taken the first two measures with industry and also within the food standards code, will be to concentrate on an educational approach to this area. Together with State Ministers, the Federal Minister for Community Services and Health, to whom I am indirectly related in this portfolio because of our joint interest in the food standards code, will be encouraging State governments to promote educational activities to ensure that the principles of the World Health Organisation code are implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Does the Minister confirm or deny that the Government intends to sell the Anzac Rifle Range in Sydney, just like it sold the Williamstown range in Victoria? Can he tell the Senate whether representations have been received from the National Rifle Association of New South Wales to retain that range for the purposes for which it was originally developed? If so, can he tell us the present situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I am aware, the intention to sell the rifle range still remains, although my understanding is that the Department of Administrative Services has had some difficulty with the tendering. To know what stage that has reached one really needs to ask the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I cannot give the details of what has happened, except to say that my understanding is that the Government's announced decision to sell the rifle range has not been changed.

ANSWER.PARA: Negotiations have been entered into with the National Rifle Association, or whichever organisation was using the premises. I recall that it had a very long lease of the premises. As far as the details are concerned, they are not the responsibility of the Department of Defence but of the Department of Administrative Services and I will have to refer the matter to my colleague.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today Senator Walsh again tried to trivialise the fall of $56 in the living standard since this Government came to power in March 1983. additional SWF trapping devices have been located at strategic sites and at points of high animal concentrations, such as abattoirs, within a 50 km radius of Darwin
surveillance for myiasis in man is being carried out in co-operation with State Health Departments
a producer awareness program was initiated to have producers inspect stock, report suspicious cases and to submit samples of larvae for identification.
(b) Current procedures for livestock vessels to ensure freedom from insects are:
disinfection of the vessel within 48 hours prior to docking
inspection of the vessel either at, or prior to, the quarantine line which entails
visual inspection of all livestock compartments, holds and galleys for evidence of live and dead insects
examination of the Ships Log and empty insecticide containers
if live insects are observed the vessels will require re-disinfection before docking is approved
insectocutors are placed on livestock vessels either at the Quarantine line or after docking to assist in the monitoring of the procedures.
These procedures are currently under review by Government and industry to enhance the effectiveness of the disinfection and surveillance procedures.
(c) Monitoring programs at Australian ports vary between southern and northern ports
in northern ports, insectocutors are placed on the vessels during the time in port and these are inspected and cleaned daily
in southern ports, limited monitoring as above is undertaken at most ports.

(d) It is unlikely that there would be any prohibition or restriction placed on livestock or meat exported from Australia should the Screw-worm fly establish in Australia. However it is expected that export livestock would need to be inspected for the presence of SWF larvae.
(e) No additional costs would be involved for Australian exports as all live animals are currently inspected prior to export.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 30 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the incidence of potato cyst nematode in New Zealand potatoes, under what conditions is it possible to import New Zealand potatoes into Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Potatoes can be imported only for processing and only from defined areas in New Zealand which are free of black wart disease and potato cyst nematode (PCN). All imports must be to approved premises in metropolitan areas under quarantine supervision.

Following the discovery in March this year of PCN in the Manawatu-Rangiteiki district of North Island there are currently no potato growing areas in New Zealand which satisfy Australia's requirement for freedom from the disease.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 30 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the incidence of fire blight in New Zealand apples, under what conditions is it possible to import New Zealand apples into Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The conditions for importation of apples from New Zealand are prescribed in the Quarantine (Plants) Regulations under the Quarantine Act. The regulations require certification by the New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries that apples are produced in districts where fire blight does not occur.
In practice New Zealand officials have not been able to provide this certification therefore apple imports from New Zealand have not been permitted.
Australia recently rejected New Zealand proposals for certifying orchards free from the disease as it could not be demonstrated that they were adequately isolated from other orchards.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November 1987 (Hansard, page 2391), Senator Coulter asked Senator Walsh, as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, a question without notice concerning the occurrence of cadmium in Australian food. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia does not have the sort of cadmium pollution that occurs in the industrial countries of the northern hemisphere and therefore the use of the word pollution to describe the Australian situation is somewhat exaggerated. Some incremental cadmium may accrue from the application of fertilizers derived from phosphatic deposits and this may be of significance in areas where other factors, such as soil acidity, favour uptake by plants.

Directly or indirectly, soil is the source of cadmium for grazing cattle and sheep, but the distribution of high cadmium levels in the kidneys of sheep and cattle is not always correlated with the use of phosphatic fertilizers. The factors governing uptake and accumulation of cadmium in plant and animal tissues are complex and not well understood.
Kidney levels tend to increase with age, and higher levels are found in females than in males. Kidneys have higher levels than liver and negligible levels are found in muscle.

The 1986 National Residue Survey found 7 per cent of wheat samples analysed for cadmium to contain more than 0.05 mg/kg of cadmium. In the 1987 survey period only 2.86 per cent of samples were above 0.05 mg/kg. Since that period no further violations on wheat have been reported.

There is no record of a shipment of Australian wheat being rejected by Sweden because of cadmium contamination. Indeed, the last shipment of Australian wheat direct to Sweden appears to have been made in 1953. Sweden is a net exporter of wheat and is only a small and irregular importer.

The 1986 National Residue Survey found that 21.3 per cent of sheep kidneys and 12 per cent of beef kidneys sampled exceeded the Australian standard of 2.5 mg/kg for bovine and ovine kidney. The Western Australian data showed 47.1 per cent of sheep kidneys exceeded that level, not 75 per cent as mentioned by the honourable Senator.

The samples analysed since 1986 show a somewhat lower incidence of levels exceeding the Australian standard. Only 8.6 per cent of sheep kidneys and 4.7 per cent of cattle kidneys had levels above 2.5 mg/kg, while the figures for Western Australia were 26.8 per cent for sheep and 14.7 per cent for cattle.

The complex issues governing the uptake of cadmium by plants and animals are being investigated by the Bureau of Rural Resources in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in close consultation with State agencies, the CSIRO and the NH&MRC.
